Despite that, he probably was "smeared" by the Tudor historians in the service of Henry VII, who had a vested interest in making RIchard out to be a terrible villain, and Henry VIII, who had the same interest.

The argument that the princes were no threat to Richard because they had been declared illegitimate is worthless. Illegitimate children have been legitimated and legitimate ones illegitimated time and again. Illegitimate(d) children have served as pretexts for uprisings and overthrows. France in 1920's vs USA 2013 - comparing apples and oranges.
Totally different cirumstances. For instance, trade and finance structure and interconnection were not global in the 1920's like it is today. Also, the USD was not the world's reserve currency. And China was not an emerging economy building a huge reserve of gold.

You also mention that "there was no sustained economic downturn" - this may have been so in 1920's France, but not so in 2000's USA. Check-out the website "Shadowstats" for a more accurate picture of just how well the US economy has been travelling since 2008 (ie; calculating CPI & unemployment using the formulae before the US government changed the way these stats were calcuated in order to now paint a more "rosey" picture than actual reality). Why are there 46 million people on food stamps (and climbing)? These stats are representative of sustained economic downturn.

The USA has entered into currency wars with China and now Japan. To imply that the USA can "print-away" their debt and come out the other end unscathed is, at best, extremely optimistic.

Doctor, why don't you read Kyle's book before rendering a diagnosis? It is unethical to make a diagnosis without examining the patient. Perhaps he rationalizes what he has done so that he does not end up like his killer.  By the way, to those that refer to Kyle as a soldier - he was a sailor.

That Chris Kyle was to be celebrated for doing what he did is a curious, and inevitably grotesque response to the age-old necessity in war of dehumanizing the "enemy". The fact bears more than a bit of truth, I am afraid, that someone in his position, who cold and calculatedly kills other human beings has more than a touch of the sociopath in him. There is no getting around the fact, especially when time passes by and you show not a moment of regret. We will never know whether indeed it was more than a bit of egotism that was the public face that showed no regret, but if indeed that was the case Chris Kyle should not be elevated to any humanistic superiority. He was basically a cold-blooded serial murderer who in a moment in time is absolutely necessary to the repugnant, grim reality of war, but outside of such a context not a single tear can be shed by anyone who recognizes that his work brought him elation, and pleasure.
Indeed, those that come home and end up killing themselves can arguably be said to be superior in their realization that they killed human beings as "innocent" as they, and cannot live with the lowliness of their acts.

One problem with data collection is that in order to maintain consistency, the questions asked have to be simplified. Data collection is a blunt instrument. In the paring-down process, a lot of the interesting nuances get pushed aside. Just think of a time when you've been polled about something over the telephone: usually, you get yes/no options, occasionally you can say "maybe" or "sometimes," but that's about as delicately shaded as it gets.

Another problem is that data collection is rarely (if ever) a global project; many people may collect data on the same essential question, but their wording is different, or they use different criteria for selection, or reporting procedures are different, all of which makes aggregating the differently collected data difficult at best and makes for sloppy comparisons.

Not to say data are useless, but as David suggests, it isn't the be-all and end-all of anything.

The problem with Chris Kyle is that he committed himself to a war that was based on a lie.

There were no WMDs. Our human rights abuses were as bad as Saddam Hussein's. We wanted to replace one dictator (Saddam Hussein), with another (Ahmed Chalabai). Saddam Hussein wasn't helping al-Qaeda. The war itself helped al-Qaeda. There is no democracy, just tribal leaders, religious leaders, and strong men. What was the *real* reason for the war? You tell me.

The deal that a soldier makes is that he will follow orders. I can respect that. I can respect Kyle and others who fought in Iraq for their courage and commitment. But I also have to respect the soldiers of any army, including our enemies.

We invaded their country. The Iraqis were defending themselves. One soldier who lost his arm to an IED said, "I don't blame them. If they invaded Texas, I would have done the same thing."

About 4,500 American military personnel were killed in the war. But between 150,000 and 600,000 Iraqis, mostly civilians, were killed.

I can't praise somebody who ignorantly or thoughtlessly committed himself to a death toll like that. That includes Kyle, everyone else who volunteered and believed Bush -- and journalists for the New York Times who have even less excuse for believing those lies.
